content:
It would be good to have a test case that ends in "0" and has multiple digits (>2), like "230".

I just got this in shortest mode and made a bad call that got me 100% on tests but 75% on validators. It was due to evaluating the reversed strings into integers, but in Ruby when you evaluate "032" (230 backwards) it assumes it's octal and evaluates to 26 rather than 32.

Silly mistake, but it would be nice if such edge cases were debuggable in the test cases and not just validators. Fun clash though!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good but could have a more elaborate description.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and efficient, but the goal could be slightly more explicit.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Parfait pour un clash

Maybe I misunderstood the goal, but it appears to me that you're asking to build a palindromic number starting from your input value. In my opinion, the word 'hidden' would imply that the palindrome already lies in your input value, which is not the case.

If this exercise is based on a mathematical theorem (which you imply from your first sentence : For almost every integer resides a hidden palindrome), I would suggest to add a reference to the corresponding maths.

Your contribution has been uploaded twice. Please remove one of them. The other link is:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/608686fdc7e8d19922b6515ee2d798bbb75e9

Also, a similar clash exists, although that one requires the output to include all the steps from start to end:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/44540edf94aff0f000b0186288c2f57e37c

Thanks.
I would agree. The goal could be worded a bit better
